did.head: Collection Overview

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Center of the Creative and Performing Arts

did.physdesc: 12.5 linear feet (172 reel to reel tapes in 15 cartons, 324 audio cassettes in 6 boxes, 1 external hard drive)
did.langmaterial: Collection material includes spoken word recordings in English.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The collection contains 172 original reel to reel tape recordings of 113 recitals containing approximately 613 works. The works range from the Renaissance to music created for the concerts, even improvised at the events. The reels are accompanied by audio cassette recordings created as service copies and a hard drive containing digitally reformatted preservation and access files.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Recordings of Creative Associates Recitals, 1964-1980, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Additionally, performers' permissions were not acquired at the time of the recordings. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of State University of New York at Buffalo Music Department.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

altformavail.head: Alternate Forms
altformavail.p: The first access service copies for the reel to reel tapes were provided by copying content onto audio cassettes sometime around 1978-1980. The contents were transferred as one musical work per one cassette side. The cassettes were numbered and inventoried. The cassettes have been retained and shelved with the collection as backup copies.

The reel to reel tapes were digitized in 2018 by Northeast Document Conservation Center and the reformatted contents were delivered on a single external hard drive. Copies were transferred to a server for backup and storage. Preservation Broadcast Wave Format files matching the original reels of tape (one digital file per face of a reel) were created at 96 kHz, 24-bit resolution. Due to the discrete musical works on the tapes, production master files were then created to match the musical content, one file per work at the same resolution as the preservation masters. Access service copies matching the content of the Production master files were created as MP3 format files at 44.1 kHz, 192kbps resolution.

Digital files were named according to the following convention, all using ubmu0063 to represent the archival collection number:
Preservation file: ubmu0063_001am.wav with 001 representing the tape number and am representing Archival master
Production master file: ubmu0063_001_01am.wav with 001 representing the tape number, _01 representing the work number, and pm representing Production master
Access service file: ubmu0063_001_01sc.mp3 with 001 representing the tape number, _01 representing the work number, and pm representing Service copy

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Creative Associates Recitals were a product of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, established to give young professional performers and composers the opportunity to focus on the production of new music. Lukas Foss, Music Director for the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra 1963-1971, approached Gordon Smith, director of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery 1955-1973, to develop ideas for a Center of New Music in Buffalo. In discussions with Allan Sapp, Director of the University at Buffalo Music Department, and the Rockefeller Foundation, a proposal was submitted to the Foundation for the development of the Center. Modeled after the Evenings-on-the-Roof concert series in Los Angeles, the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts was “founded on notions of providing performing ensembles, of making definitive renditions of new and complicated music feasible, of bringing composers and performers into the closest working relationships, of developing a corpus of recordings and privately-held scores, of establishing a central locus for the study of new techniques of composition notation and performance practice.” The proposal was accepted and the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts began operation in 1964.

Directors of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts included the founders, Lukas Foss and Allan Sapp, who acted as Co-Directors from 1964-68; Lejaren Hiller, Co-Director with Lukas Foss from 1968-74; Jan Williams, Co-Director with Renée Levine from 1974-76; Renée Levine, Center Coordinator from 1964-74 and Co-Director from 1974-78; and Morton Feldman, Music Director from 1976-1980. Performers and composers selected to be fellows at the Center were given the title of Creative Associate.

There were two main concert series produced by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts: Evenings for New Music concerts and Creative Associate Recitals. Evenings for New Music concerts were performed in Buffalo and also performed, often with changes in programs, at various other venues. Creative Associates Recitals were performed within Buffalo, most often on the campus of the University at Buffalo. The Recitals were the programmed by the Creative Associates themselves as supplements to the Evenings for New Music concerts. The Associates were free to program whatever works they wished. As a result, the programs include a repertoire ranging from the Renaissance through new music composed expressly for the recitals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains recordings of approximately 613 works performed on 113 of the 127 recitals presented 1964-1980 by the Creative Associates of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts. A complete listing of all the concerts, including works and concerts not recorded, can be seen in the original inventory online.

The music of more than 200 composers is represented in the collection. Due to the eclectic nature of the progamming, a wide range of composers is included, from the 14th to 20th centuries. Music from the 20th century spans a diverse spectrum of musical styles from more traditional to avant garde. Composers whose works were performed include Crumb, Berio, Wuorinen, Carter, Copland, Bussotti, Scelsi, Feldman, Cage, as well as lesser-known figures whose representation here may be rare. Performers included some of the most skilled practicioners of contemporary music. There are also many instances of composers either performing or directing performances of their own works.

Of the new music performed, there are works that were presented in what amounted to draft versions. Upon examination, some works no longer appear on the works lists of their composers. As a result, these recordings could represent the only surviving documentation of some of the compositions performed. Close to 20 premieres were performed. Some recordings require more research to fully describe due the practice of performing multiple works simultaneously or other factors that make clear definition challenging.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series according to format.

scopecontent.p: This series contains all the 172 original reel to reel recordings.

arrangement.p: Chronologically arranged by concert and then by order on the program. It is important to note that the 128 known recitals were sequentially numbered in chronological order based on supplementary documentation such as concert programs. There are gaps in the sequence below for the fifteen concerts not recorded. However, the reels were sequentially numbered based on what was in hand. As a result, their numbering does not correlate to the recital numbering. Work numbering was based on where the work is on a tape, not where it may have been stated on a printed program. There are many cases where programs were changed at the time of performance. The tapes have been grouped and listed according to the concerts. Original concert programs are included with most of the tapes. These often contain markings by the recording engineers regarding program order and technical issues of the recording such as tape speed or exceptional conditions.

It is not the same performance as that on CA080.

scopecontent.p: Recorded sides are numbered 1-707. The dates above represent the dates of the original recordings, not the dates the cassettes were created as transfers from the reel to reel tapes.

arrangement.p: Arranged in numerical order which also chiefly represents chronological order.
